text: Im on the spikier side but i like to have clear rules. Its not clear to me what an “acceptable” hand is and i think since each persons defininition is people will do it differently. Is playable i have enough lands? Is playable in a deck with a high curve mean i have lands and ramp?
That being said in my at home playgroup we let people draw up to 7 if they mull past 7. But in public it seems fine
How did this become an argument? Lol
I think, in here at least, we’re really just discussing. I made a statement on Twitter that I always let people free mull because I’d rather have a decent game for everyone than someone sit out.

I guess when I say "acceptable hand" I mean not one-landers or hands where you're presumably going to sit the first five turns passing because you have all 6 drops and 2 lands and nothing else to do. Maybe my issue is more that I see a lot of people not mulliganing aggressively enough and keeping risky hands. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Yeah i think im the same way seth. I usually tell people to draw up to 7 if the table is people i know
That's probably another thing I'm not taking in account. I'm mostly thinking back to when Dani and I hosted the big group we had in SC out of our kitchen. So we knew pretty much everyone coming over.
I also wont ask people if i can draw up to 7
Ill wait to see if someone offers and if not im not even slightly salty about it

I have asked, when I get down to a 4-card mulligan and still not seeing at least 2 lands. But then, I have also asked people if they mind if I just grab a different deck, putting the problematic one aside to check land counts afterward
I have noticed fewer problems since upping my standard land count to 38 from my previous 36
Thats a good approach seth
Also having upped my landcount and paying attention to my average cmc i rarely mull anymore
Meanwhile my friend that runs a average cmc of whats got to be 6 mulls every game and then complains when his deckdoes nothing
LOL, yeah I try to aim closer to a 3.2 curve, but I do have some decks that are higher. Kiora has like a 3.7, but there's also tons of ramp in the deck

I built a deck years ago and took it to a friends house to test. It played like crap all night, I was mana screwed, had to mull constantly, etc. I knew the avg cmc was high but it was shocking g how poorly it worked. Two days later I found the pile of 14 lands in my desk I hadn’t shuffled in. Apparently 22 isn’t enough in Commander.
LOL, that's rough man

I did something similar-ish. I swear I counted my lands twice for Kiora and got 38, but when I put the decklist on Deckstats, 32 O.O Where did my six cards go?! And, unlucky/lucky me, I realized the land count after adding 6 more cards, thinking I had the right amount of lands but hadn't picked out 62 cards... I wound up liking the six new cards so much, I took out other cards for the land spots XD

Fun fact, Dani's first iteration of Ezuri Elves ran on 21 lands.

And did great nearly every game. It was the most frustrating thing I have ever experienced in Commander. Made no mathematical sense.
"I curve out at like 7 mana, so I figured 8 lands was enough to be safe"
That math checks out.
I want to smash my face into my desk
<https://twitter.com/medina_mtg/status/1144296690305966080>

attachments.fallback:

Have you noticed the same thing? What are your thoughts on this post? 

#MTG #MagicTheGathering <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/D-FbxbBXUAE8eQ1.jpg>
attachments.text:
I’m not sure how I feel about this post by <https://twitter.com/SheldonMenery|@SheldonMenery>. I’ve noticed a growing sentiment in the #CMDR community that frowns on optimized decks and combos. 

Have you noticed the same thing? What are your thoughts on this post? 

#MTG #MagicTheGathering <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/D-FbxbBXUAE8eQ1.jpg>

text: Games gotta end. I like playing interactive games but if we're approaching some sort of a board stall after an hour of battelcruiser and someone hits some 3 card combo that nobody else can answer, let's shuffle up and play again
I tend to notice, but Sheldon always seems to throw a line in "I'm not trying to do this thing" (demonize combos in this instance) and then proceeds to, in my opinion, do that very thing
Sometimes I wonder what the average length of his games are within his playgroup

I agree with him, honestly. In general over time, most playgroups tend toward stronger and stronger play, ostracizing players who can't keep up as they go.

That said, I'm not sure infinite combos are the culprit here. They can be fine if they're crazy enough or slow enough or unlikely enough and still end long games as Matt describes. But there is still always gonna be that guy that shows up to a group playing just above precons with Mike and Trike and then is surprised when people are pissed about it.
That's power level as usual, not combos being bad.
Got to disagree with him. I do have those decks that dont combo out, and let alone my feelings, they're not fun for others to play
Do people really want me swinging at someone to death with a 3/3 turn by turn?
Nah, you should always have a plan to win.
That plan just needs to take into account the power level of the group. That's all.

Iunno, I've run combos in my decks and I just don't do the whole "tutor it out every game"

(Except Krenko)
I about punched my windshield when it came to that topic coming up on the podcast, actually.
Playing your deck badly on purpose is _not_ balancing power levels.
Don't do that, windshields cost money
It's okay, the mining trucks around here are constantly cracking them anyway.
It's not about playing it badly, it's about playing for the situation. I tutor up answers, not just trudge toward my end game, oblivious to things around the table

In any case, playing your deck badly on purpose is offensive if anyone at the table knows you're doing it.

When it comes to tutors, you can have tutors and toolbox without "hey tutor this and you win", or you can have "hey play this and you win" without tutors. You can't have both.
If you're trying to play at a lower power level, anyway.

I think there's something to be said for "playing to the audience" in a more casual setting. If you're tutoring, you have a choice. You can choose to tutor up the "optimal" card or the fun card. The choice is yours
The problem is, if people know that you're not winning on purpose, that gets feelings rising quickly.
If the Vanifar player Joey and I came across tutored up some toolbox pieces or some answers we would have probably been more open to playing with them again compared to them combo-ing out t4
Agreed, but I'd much rather play against someone with a toolbox Vanifar in the first place. Why even build it the other way if you're not going to use it that way?
It also depends a bit on if the tutored card is going to win right now or not
If I need two pieces and I can only tutor one, or an answer, the answer might be better
Especially since cards like Windfall and other wheels are popular
I still disagree that it's "playing badly" and I think that's a really aggressive way of thinking about it. But I'm sure I'm biased because, well, I disagree :stuck_out_tongue:

One way or another, you're looking down on others when you aren't playing your deck to win. If it's your playgroup, they know you're holding back and coddling the table and could just win any time you wanted. If it's new people, then you're disrespecting them before you've even met them, rather than just taking the time to figure out what level they're playing at.
The only time it really makes sense at all is with brand new players to the game.
If you're teaching, taking it easy on them makes sense. Otherwise...
That's your opinion, then.
I think he's mostly right on

I mean, I get it to a degree. Not everyone loves brewing decks so just jamming an established Labman combo or Thopter/Sword, Mike/Trike etc makes sense if you just wanna play and have a chance to win. I've talked it on the cast a bit, but it took me months and months to find the lines in my Vela deck. It's nuts to expect people to do that. And it's often easier to tweak up to match that power deck than it is to tweak down, particularly because at the risk of reading too much into a player's playstyle, someone who shows up with a deck radically stronger than the meta and keeps doing that probably isn't the kind of person really interested in what anyone else around them likes.
They're just not down-tuning at your request; they'd have done it already if they gave a shit after crushing someone's Seinfeld theme deck week in and week out.
So people power up to match since getting frogstomped every week sucks.

It's not healthy for the format, though as the faster and more combo-y the decks get the narrower the field of playable commanders and cards get, the more the price goes up, and the more people get excluded.
That said, I do think Sheldon maybe leans a little too much into dudes slamming Craw Wurms into each other as his optimal vision of the format.
That's my kinda clinical take. My personal take? Most combos I see in the wild are lazy af, and they're used by intellectually lazy people.
Not all. There's nothing inherently lazy about combo as a concept. I've seen some wonky Rube Goldberg contraptions and some really clever ones plenty often.
But when someone says they comboed out to win, it's almost always the same 4-5 cliched common combos that somebody tutored up a piece, then patted themselves on the back for the win after.

There's a whole lot of people who say they like interactive games, but what that really means is they like interactive games until it looks like they might lose, then they tutor up their combo and protect it with a Negate and a Force of Will.

There were a couple exploits in old football games where if you new the trick you could almost always auto-sack the QB after the snap with the right defensive player. There was a guy in the dorms when we played who used to play "fair" games almost all the time . . . unless the score was close. Then he'd miraculously get a couple of defensive sacks in the fourth quarter to seal the win.
There's a whole lot of combo players that do the EDH equivalent of that in my experience.

Makes it tough for commander products; they're designed to facilitate interactive games, especially cards that encourage combat. You know which cards we want reprinted? The cards that don't encourage combat and let us accrue more efficient value. Veeeeery awkward position as a product designer
I mean, I write an entire series about card optimization, so I'm guilty of it to a degree.

I also think fast combo is the kind of thing a lot of people are fine with dropping on unsuspecting players. <@U7VNVRSMC> likes a playstyle that would make me commit seppiku, but I also get the impression she just plays that way with people well aware the decks she plays are gonna require you to have a protractor and a quart of gin handy. It's also a playstyle that doesn't warp a meta around it; you don't have to respond to chaos with chaos to have a chance.
Get out the rubber sheets.
Dana did you breath in between any of those sentences?
I've evolved beyond such petty human needs
btw, Kya, I really had to try not to just start writing paragraphs about Chaos Zedruu while reviewing [[Agent of Treachery]].

attachments.fallback: Agent of Treachery {5}{U}{U} // Creature — Human Rogue // When Agent of Treachery enters the battlefield, gain control of target permanent. // At the beginning of your end step, if you control three or more permanents you don't own, draw three cards. // 2/3
attachments.text:
Creature — Human Rogue
When Agent of Treachery enters the battlefield, gain control of target permanent.
At the beginning of your end step, if you control three or more permanents you don't own, draw three cards.
_"The more secrets you have, the more easily you become my pawn."_
*2/3*
attachments.title: Agent of Treachery {5}{U}{U}

text: This is kind of divisive(I think), but I don't think it's healthy to keep printing these 3 colors tribal commanders. I saw the Prof's reply to Gavin's post and he wanted a Bant merfolk tribal commander. Giving a tribe that kind of commander is basically reducing choices for that tribe. Thoughts?
Part of the problem is that time is limited, some people don't play enough. I'm lucky if I get a multiplayer commander game night more than once a month.
I would agree, but I also don't because those of us who do have the wherewithall to just not make the best version of a thing because it exists suffer a bit.
I think the Prof asking for that is kind of the "we want everything" attitude that just because they COULD have it means they SHOULD have it. Restrictions and all that
I do think it's a matter of time until they do that though
So they're going to more specifically aim for the thing that is more fun for them. For me, it's crazy stories and fun games. For others, it's winning.
If folks played more often, they might not have to spend as much time and focus on "this specific thing that I care about".

I mentioned this in the show we recorded last night, but while the new hydra guy might be more useful as gruul, at that point he's bar none the best hydra commander. At mono-g? You have to make a choice then between him at green, or something else in gruul or jund.
That's why I've got ten janky commander decks instead of 3 decent ones.
So I get some of those design decisions
Doooo it Doug... become one with the void
Wow, that conversation caught on awhile I drove home :stuck_out_tongue:
<@UEF135G05> to a certain extent, if you're able to play more often, you only suffer if you subject yourself to the same meta.
Commander is a casual format; in other words, it's a social format.
Some folks just lose sight of that.

Yep. I have a Jeskai tokens deck that didn't have an "optimal commander". Instead of just not building it I made it w/ a suboptimal commander. I know I'm going to switch it to Kykar because there's little reason not to
Exactly, and as part of the "social" format, you get to have the power lever conversation before you start playing.
I think artifacts decks suffered a bit of that when Breya was released, right? Very little reason to not just splash a couple of colors and get the best support you could hope for
I know for a fact that I'm not that good of a player, specially in multiplayer.
In paper at least, I get anxious and end up playing loose. One time I discarded to hand size 2 turns in a row (land tax) with a reliquary tower in hand.
Join the club man. I played 2 full games w/ Teysa Karlov until I realized that opponents creatures dying also made my things trigger twice
Im late to the party but i agree with sheldon
In my perfect world more wincons would be viable across spectrums of competitiveness
That was not the message that I got from his post at all O.o
Sheldon said he has concerns about a format dominated by combos as win conditions first and foremost. It reads to me as advocacy for a diversity of efficient win conditions
You definitely don't hear people pushing you to win with combat damage because it's efficient these days. And that's a problem with diversity.
I still think starting life totals should be 30.

Was there more to the post than the clip in the tweet? It mostly just sounded like him not liking the direction of Commander as a combo-win based format, specifically. I took it more as "we should be playing more vanilla creatures and smashing them into one another, that's what Commander is for" but I admit to being very biased against what I've heard from Sheldon in the past.

I've been on that train for awhile, Dean. I think it'd be a good change for aggressive decks
There are direct and indirect messages in every communication
I mean, to be fair, we should be playing more vanilla creatures and slamming them into each other.  Everybody should have at least one jank deck.

I guess whats the difference between consciously playing sub-optimally and consciously building sub-optimally? If it's looking down on someone to play with their experience in mind and not try to beat them as quick as possible is somehow different to build a deck that way in your mind?
What do you all think about people who's goal isnt to just win, but establish some boardstate
I guess I can't reconcile the message of choosing to not make the ideal play is disrespectful but choosing not to build the ideal deck isn't
Like a tribal deck where someone wants their army up. Or to do some crazy play? Slowly becoming more of that player
<@U7VNVRSMC> it depends if the board state works to end the game or to take 25 minute turns they ultimately do nothing.
Yeah just for this question assume I'm not talking about chaos or some stupidly complex durdle.
Like maybe just creating 100 tokens or something
What Henry said. If your board state is Solemnity/Decree of Silence I will start shuffling up for a new game without that deck

Or even if you take 20 minutes to make 250 tokens and then “pass”. It’s fine to have achievement decks but you have to measure if reaching that goal takes forever and doesn’t really progress the game.
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yz246_Pjjkc>

text: Good lord that movie had so many names in it

I mean, the biggest thrill I get out of Commander is my deck working. Working doesn't mean winning, just meaning interactions going and consistently decent showings during games. If I play the same deck 10 times and win 2, but 8 times I have a good game and I matter in the game, I think that's a good deck

Matt, to answer your question from earlier, I consider playing down very different than building down.

With building down, you're building a deck to be on the same level as others who could be new players, old players, bad players, good players, any kind of builders or players honestly. It's inclusive and can lead to hilarious matches of shirtless tribal and the like where everyone is evenly matched.

With playing down, you're excluding instead of including. You're constantly sitting there asking yourself if the people you're playing with are good enough that you should try to win or not.

> If it's looking down on someone to play with their experience in mind and not try to beat them as quick as possible is somehow different to build a deck that way in your mind?

It seems like this statement assumes that playing a bad deck means you're a bad player, which is kind of what I'm trying to get at.
I mean, we all start from the seat of "I'm not building the best deck" in EDH, so why would it be that a person would be a bad player for just turning that dial down farther?
